title: 104_hr2727
content: The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" aims to ensure that Federal regulations are only enacted by Congress as outlined in Article I of the Constitution, preventing delegation of regulatory power to unelected officials in the executive branch. The "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" requires regulations proposed by executive branch agencies to be approved by Congress, ending the practice of delegating regulatory power to unelected officials. This will make Congress more democratic and accountable, protecting the public from regulations not endorsed by elected officials. SEC. 3. ENACTMENT OF AGENCY REGULATIONS. Regulations must be approved by Congress before taking effect. Agencies must submit a report to Congress with the text and explanation of proposed regulations. SEC. 4. EXPEDITED CONGRESSIONAL PROCEDURES FOR AGENCY REGULATIONS. The bill introduced by the Majority Leader of each House of Congress must solely contain the text of the regulation submitted by an agency. If the bill is not introduced, any Member of that House may introduce it. The term "bill" refers to a legislative document that approves agency regulations to have the force of law. For any bill introduced by the Majority Leader of Congress that contains agency regulations, any Member of the House can also introduce the bill. The term "bill" refers to a legislative document approving agency regulations to have legal effect without committee referral. The text of regulations approved as law shall not be referred to a committee. Any Member can move for consideration of the bill the day after announcing their intention. All points of order against the bill are waived, and the motion is privileged in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The motion to consider a bill must be made the day after the Member announces their intention. All points of order are waived, and the motion is privileged in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. It is not debatable, amendable, or subject to postponement. The motion to consider a bill is not debatable, amendable, or subject to postponement. If the motion is agreed to, the respective House will immediately proceed to consider the bill without any intervening business. Debate on the bill and related motions is limited to one hour. Debate on the bill and related motions is limited to one hour, with equal time for those favoring and opposing the bill. Amendments are not allowed, but a motion to further limit debate is permitted. Postponement, consideration of other business, or recommitting the bill motions are not allowed. The final passage of a bill shall be divided equally between those favoring and opposing it. Amendments are not allowed, but a motion to limit debate is permitted. Appeals from the Chair's decisions on procedural regulations shall be decided without debate. The final passage of a bill must be voted on within 60 days of its introduction in Congress. A motion to suspend certain procedures can be passed with a majority vote. The final passage of a bill in Congress must occur within 60 days of its introduction. A motion to suspend certain procedures can be passed with a majority vote in either House. Upon passage of a motion with a majority vote, a bill in Congress is treated like other bills. If the other House receives a bill with the same text, it cannot be referred to a committee and can only be considered for final passage. If the House receives a bill from the other House with the same text, it cannot be referred to a committee and can only be considered for final passage. The procedure in the receiving House remains the same, but the final passage vote will be on the bill from the other House. Upon receiving a bill from the other House with the same text, the procedure in the receiving House remains the same, but the final passage vote will be on the bill from the other House. After the bill from the other House is dealt with, the original bill in the receiving House cannot be considered further. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. Defines "agency" and "regulation" in relation to this Act. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act applies to agency regulations created after its enactment. Regulations in bills from this Act are not subject to judicial review under chapter 7 of title 5, United States Code.
